module.p: feadhainn people, folk is a feminine common noun.

Examples from Gairm –
Ma rannsaicheas sinn air ais fada gu leòir chì sinn nach robh sgoilean anns an Oban gus an ochdamh linn deug. Bha an sgoil bheag a b’ fhaisge air anns a’ Chill Mhóir cóig mìle air falbh, agus tha e coltach gu robh an sgoil sin air an fheadhainn bu shine an Earra-Ghaidheal.
If we research back long enough we will see that there were no schools in Oban until the eighteenth century. The closest little school was in Kilmore five miles away, and it appears that that school was one of the oldest in Argyll. td. 363

Other examples from modern usage –
Bha a h-uile duine a dh’aithnicheadh e a’ smaoineachadh gu robh beatha shòlasach aig Ailig Smart. Bha feadhainn a’ dèanamh fealla-dhà air ainm, ag ràdh ‘Smart Ailig’, ach cha robh an sin ach farmad. [...]
Everybody who got to know him thought that Alec Smart had a good life. Some people made fun of his name, saying ‘Smart Alec’, but there was nothing there but envy. [...] td. 103
Is fhada bhon a bha daoine ag ràdh gum biodh àite cruinneachaidh do luchd-labhairt na Gàidhlig na leas do chor a’ chànain, na ghoireas don fheadhainn a bha an-sàs ann an gnìomhan Gàidhlig mar-thà agus na mheadhan air aire agus ùidh sa Ghàidhlig a thogail.
For a long time people were saying that a gathering place for Gaelic speakers would be a benefit to the state of the language, an amenity for those who were involved in Gaelic activities already and a means of raising awareness and interest in Gaelic. td. 85
